title: How to Warm Up for Crossfit

steps.headline: Pick 1 to 2 cardio exercises for the first 10-15 minutes of your warmup.
steps.description: Keep in mind that you will also need time to complete flexibility and mobility moves later in your warmup. Try doing the same exercises for 30 days so you can measure the improvement you make. Or, if you need variety to keep from getting bored, try creating a routine that changes every other day to incorporate different warmup exercises. Write out your routine and keep it on your phone so you can reference it easily and stay on track.

steps.headline: Run through the agility ladder for 5 minutes for a fast-paced exercise.
steps.description:
Set a timer for 5-10 minutes. If you are a beginner, focus on successfully completing the forward run, where each foot touches the center of each box. If you are more advanced, alternate the forward run with the lateral run, where you move sideways from end to end. Try some of these other agility ladder moves:
Hops: jump and lightly land inside each box until you get to the end. In and out: put your left foot in the first box, then the right foot. Then, put your left foot outside of the second box, and then the right. Continue moving your feet inside then outside of the boxes until you reach the end. Single leg hops: hop on 1 leg for the length of the ladder, landing inside each box along the way. Come back from the end on your other leg.

steps.headline: Jump rope for 5-10 minutes to improve your coordination.
steps.description:
Set a timer for 5-10 minutes and see how many times you can jump rope during that period. If you are a beginner, go as slow as you need to, taking care to not trip over the rope. If you are a more advanced CrossFit member, try some of these moves:
Single-leg jumps: jump rope while hopping on 1 leg for 30 seconds at a time, then switch to the other leg. Double-unders: pass the rope under your feet twice in between each jump. Try doing 2 single-jumps, 1 double-under, then 2 single-jumps, continuing until the timer goes off.

steps.headline: Do shuttle runs for 5-10 minutes if you want to improve your speed.
steps.description: Place blocks or cones at equal distances across the length of the room. From 1 end of the room, sprint to the first cone, tap it, then sprint back to the end of the room. Then, sprint to the second cone, tap it, and sprint back to the end of the room. Continue doing this, each time going to the next furthest cone, until the timer goes off. Try alternating which foot you pivot on when you reach the cone and which side you turn to—this will increase your agility.

steps.headline: Perform stair runs for 5-10 minutes to warm up your legs.
steps.description: Alternate how many steps you take at a time, whether you move forward-facing or sideways, and how quickly you ascend the stairs. On the way back down, slow down and move carefully, focusing on getting down safely rather than quickly. Focus on landing the balls of your feet firmly on each step on your way up, even if you are skipping 2 or 3 steps. This will help you keep your balance and momentum.

steps.headline: Execute as many burpees as you can for an all body warmup.
steps.description: Set a timer for 5 minutes. Squat down and place your hands on the ground outside of and in front of your feet. Jump your feet back, getting into a planking position. Do a push-up, touching your chest to the floor (drop to your knees and do a push up if you are a beginner), return to a planking position, jump your feet forward so you’re back into a squat, then jump into the air, with your arms extended straight up. Don’t rest in the middle of your set of burpees; instead, just pace yourself and move slower, but don’t stop. Count how many burpees you can do in 5 minutes and track your progress over 30 days to see how much you improve.

steps.headline: Choose 1-3 mobility exercises to make up 10 minutes of your warmup.
steps.description: Work on squats, lunges, or leg circles for the lower body, and do push-ups, planks, or supermans to work your upper body and posture. Depending on which areas you need to strengthen or stretch, choose specific exercises to target those areas. From shoulder to hips to knees to wrists, there are exercises that can be done for each area to help strengthen your body and protect you from injury. Ask your CrossFit coach for instructions or look online to find targeted exercises. If you do get injured, visit a doctor or a physical therapist before returning to CrossFit. Preventative exercises are important, but if you are already injured, you need to get clearance before returning to the gym to prevent further damage to your body.

steps.headline: Use a foam roller to do thoracic extensions if you have tight shoulders.
steps.description: Sit on the floor and place a foam roller behind you. Lower your back onto it, so it extends from shoulder to shoulder, across the upper area of your back. Bend your knees and put your hands behind your head. Gently roll your shoulders back toward the ground to press the foam roller into the muscles of your back. You can also slightly lift your bottom from the ground and roll back over the roller, so your knees are slightly extended, to work the muscles in your lower back. A foam roller also helps massage your muscles.

steps.headline: Do a set of shoulder circles to work on your shoulder stability.
steps.description: Elevate your arms and keep them extended. Rotate your arms in tight circles for 3-5 minutes without resting them. Do 3 sets of 10 stretches.If you want to include weights, hold a dumbbell or kettleball in each hand with your body bent forward at the hips. Circle for arms for 3 sets of 10 reps each.

steps.headline: Complete hip rotation stretches to stretch your lower back and hips.
steps.description: Set a timer for 2 minutes. Lay down on your back with your knees bent. Cross your right ankle over your left knee and gently push your knee forward to stretch your hip. Hold that movement for 30-60 seconds, then switch to stretch the other side. Try placing your knees at different angles for each stretch to help your mobility.

tyn: Agility ladder or tape/chalk to make a ladder on the ground
text:
Increasing Your Heart Rate Pick 1 to 2 cardio exercises for the first 10-15 minutes of your warmup. Keep in mind that you will also need time to complete flexibility and mobility moves later in your warmup. Try doing the same exercises for 30 days so you can measure the improvement you make. Or, if you need variety to keep from getting bored, try creating a routine that changes every other day to incorporate different warmup exercises. Write out your routine and keep it on your phone so you can reference it easily and stay on track. Run through the agility ladder for 5 minutes for a fast-paced exercise. Set a timer for 5-10 minutes. If you are a beginner, focus on successfully completing the forward run, where each foot touches the center of each box. If you are more advanced, alternate the forward run with the lateral run, where you move sideways from end to end. Try some of these other agility ladder moves:
Hops: jump and lightly land inside each box until you get to the end. In and out: put your left foot in the first box, then the right foot. Then, put your left foot outside of the second box, and then the right. Continue moving your feet inside then outside of the boxes until you reach the end. Single leg hops: hop on 1 leg for the length of the ladder, landing inside each box along the way. Come back from the end on your other leg. Jump rope for 5-10 minutes to improve your coordination. Set a timer for 5-10 minutes and see how many times you can jump rope during that period. If you are a beginner, go as slow as you need to, taking care to not trip over the rope. If you are a more advanced CrossFit member, try some of these moves:
Single-leg jumps: jump rope while hopping on 1 leg for 30 seconds at a time, then switch to the other leg. Double-unders: pass the rope under your feet twice in between each jump. Try doing 2 single-jumps, 1 double-under, then 2 single-jumps, continuing until the timer goes off. Do shuttle runs for 5-10 minutes if you want to improve your speed. Place blocks or cones at equal distances across the length of the room. From 1 end of the room, sprint to the first cone, tap it, then sprint back to the end of the room. Then, sprint to the second cone, tap it, and sprint back to the end of the room. Continue doing this, each time going to the next furthest cone, until the timer goes off. Try alternating which foot you pivot on when you reach the cone and which side you turn to—this will increase your agility. Perform stair runs for 5-10 minutes to warm up your legs. Alternate how many steps you take at a time, whether you move forward-facing or sideways, and how quickly you ascend the stairs. On the way back down, slow down and move carefully, focusing on getting down safely rather than quickly. Focus on landing the balls of your feet firmly on each step on your way up, even if you are skipping 2 or 3 steps. This will help you keep your balance and momentum. Execute as many burpees as you can for an all body warmup. Set a timer for 5 minutes. Squat down and place your hands on the ground outside of and in front of your feet. Jump your feet back, getting into a planking position. Do a push-up, touching your chest to the floor (drop to your knees and do a push up if you are a beginner), return to a planking position, jump your feet forward so you’re back into a squat, then jump into the air, with your arms extended straight up. Don’t rest in the middle of your set of burpees; instead, just pace yourself and move slower, but don’t stop. Count how many burpees you can do in 5 minutes and track your progress over 30 days to see how much you improve. Targeting Mobility and Flexibility Issues Choose 1-3 mobility exercises to make up 10 minutes of your warmup. Work on squats, lunges, or leg circles for the lower body, and do push-ups, planks, or supermans to work your upper body and posture. Depending on which areas you need to strengthen or stretch, choose specific exercises to target those areas. From shoulder to hips to knees to wrists, there are exercises that can be done for each area to help strengthen your body and protect you from injury. Ask your CrossFit coach for instructions or look online to find targeted exercises. If you do get injured, visit a doctor or a physical therapist before returning to CrossFit. Preventative exercises are important, but if you are already injured, you need to get clearance before returning to the gym to prevent further damage to your body. Use a foam roller to do thoracic extensions if you have tight shoulders. Sit on the floor and place a foam roller behind you. Lower your back onto it, so it extends from shoulder to shoulder, across the upper area of your back. Bend your knees and put your hands behind your head. Gently roll your shoulders back toward the ground to press the foam roller into the muscles of your back. You can also slightly lift your bottom from the ground and roll back over the roller, so your knees are slightly extended, to work the muscles in your lower back. A foam roller also helps massage your muscles. Do a set of shoulder circles to work on your shoulder stability. Elevate your arms and keep them extended. Rotate your arms in tight circles for 3-5 minutes without resting them. Do 3 sets of 10 stretches.If you want to include weights, hold a dumbbell or kettleball in each hand with your body bent forward at the hips. Circle for arms for 3 sets of 10 reps each. Complete hip rotation stretches to stretch your lower back and hips. Set a timer for 2 minutes. Lay down on your back with your knees bent. Cross your right ankle over your left knee and gently push your knee forward to stretch your hip. Hold that movement for 30-60 seconds, then switch to stretch the other side. Try placing your knees at different angles for each stretch to help your mobility.

Keep in mind that you will also need time to complete flexibility and mobility moves later in your warmup.
Try doing the same exercises for 30 days so you can measure the improvement you make.
Or, if you need variety to keep from getting bored, try creating a routine that changes every other day to incorporate different warmup exercises.

If you are more advanced, alternate the forward run with the lateral run, where you move sideways from end to end.

Try some of these other agility ladder moves:

You can also slightly lift your bottom from the ground and roll back over the roller, so your knees are slightly extended, to work the muscles in your lower back.

Try placing your knees at different angles for each stretch to help your mobility.
